The Johns Hopkins University Barnstormers will continue
their successful all-comedy policy
as they present N. Richard
Nash's "The Rainmaker," a
Poetic" comedy in three acts,
tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 in
Shriver Hall.
The play enjoyed lengthy success on the Broadway stage and
Was later adapted into a movie
starring
Katherine Hepburn,
/31-irt Lancaster and Wendell
Corey. Set on a farm in the
rnicl-west, it concerns the plight
of a "plain" girl unhappily resigned to a fate as an old maid.
The continued efforts of her
father and brother to introduce
her to eligible bachelors meet
With no success, but she is eventually awakened to love by the
Poetic advances of a wandering
cen-man who claims to be able
to cause rainfall at will.
The lively plot thickens when
the girl and the community discover that the "rainmaker" is
a fraud and his escape forces
everyone to make some important decisions.
Lester Wolfe will direct the
Production, which stars Judy
8lank as Lizzie, the heroine:
Pete Berest as Starbuck, the
een-man, and Ralph Bonaker as
41. C. Curry, one of Lizzie's reluctant suitors. Supporting roles
Will be played by Chips Lickson,
Pete Adams and Gordon Bockher. Dick McCarty and Webster
vord are in charge of props, sets
and lighting.

Numerous Freshmen Flunk
Honor Commission Tests
Honor Commission Chairman
Cleveland Miller said this week
that it is "my impression" that
more freshmen this year than in
former years had to be privately
interviewed as a result of the
tests they took on the Honor
System at the end of Orientation
Week.
A regular part of each year's
program,
Orientation
Honor
these tests are used to determine how well incoming freshmen understand the principles
of the Honor System at Johns
Hopkins. Students whose tests
reveal inadequate understanding
receive further instruction by
members of the Commission.
Miller said, however, that this

apparent result of the tests is
not final, since "the results are
not completely in yet, nor can
they really be judged for four
more years." He continued, "I'm
not sure of the cause for this—
whether it's the result of our
tougher marking system this
year or of bad orientation on
our part. I don't think that it's
because of bad orientation, because from talking to Honor
Commission members who spoke
to the different Orientation
groups, I think that this part
of it went off well. So I'm inclined to think this is owing to
another source, and I'm not sure
what this other source is .. . It
might, in fact, be more effective
(Continued on Page 3)

The National Defense Education Act of 1958 has
generated enough nationwide electricity to cause a growing number of schools to refuse or drop the loan program
it features.
A special News-Letter survey has pinpointed tile
disclaimer affidavit (see insert, below) as the prime cause
for the controversy and disclosed several interesting sidelights among views of college presidents who oppose the
program as it now stands.
The Act itself, of which the loan provision is a part,
provides for nine government dollars to match every
one dollar the institution puts up for scholarships for
students who qualify, particularly those who plan to
teach in the public schools, or those who show superior
capacity in science, engineering, mathematics or modern
foreign language.
Applicants must in discussion show need for scholarship,aid, take an oath of allegiance to the United States,
its Constitution and laws and sign an affidavit of disbelief in organizations teaching

Zealots lot As Earth Nears End
By HARRY LAMBRIGHT
Is the end of the world coming in January? A number of
Hopkins students seem to think
so.
Something between a revival
meeting and a small-scale riot
broke out in front of the old
dorms Tuesday night as approximately 75 students raised cain
for about an hour and a half,
and succeded in attracting the
attention of a Baltimore Sun
reporter.
There had been pinned up on
the dormitory post office bulletin
board notices to the effect that
certain prognostications, made
by men whose predictions had
proven remarkably accurate in
the past, alleged that World War
III would begin in January and
would annihilate most of the
world's inhabitants.
Dire Forebodings
The reports noted that Nostradamus, a medieval monk
famed for his ability to foresee
the future, had .stated that
World War III would start between January 1 - 3, 1960; and
that Padre Pio, a man who had
predicted the dates of World
War I and II and the Korean
War, had warned that on the

coldest day of January, 1960, a
cataclasm would occur which
would result in 80% of the
world's population being slaughtered. He further predicted that
President Dwight Eisenhower
would be assassinated in New
Delhi this week.
In addition, a note was posted
which revealed that there was a
letter from the Fatima apparition, of the first quarter of this
century, which was to be opened
on January 1, 1960, and which
was "very important."
How true any of these allegations were the News-Letter was
unable to determine; what is true
is that they were sufficient excuse for a number of frenzied
zealots to congregate outside the
old dorm to follow the incantations of a bearded self-styled
leader in cheers, shouts, singing
of religious songs, the explosion
of fire crackers, and the election
of a Messiah.
"Repent," Yells Leader
"Repent," yelled the bearded
one, framed in the glow of several flashlights as he stood on
the wall of the dormitory courtyard.
Immediately his "followers"
exploded in unison with "Give

Me That Old Time Religion,"
"Swing Low, Sweet Chariot" and
"The Battle Hymn of the Republic."
"Are there any non-believers
among us?" questioned their
leader, and a mixture of "yeas"

and "nays" answered.
Activity was not limited to the
courtyard, however, for lights in
Vincent and Willard Houses kept
flashing on and off to simulate
lightning. A silhouette in a

to April 2.

include meetings with leaders in
all these fields, such as Governor
Munoz Mann, and university
presidents.
All those interested in participating are requested to inquire
at the YMCA office for further
information.

How effective?
Questioned about the effectiveness of the Honor System at
Hopkins, Miller said, "You have
to realize that an honor system
can never be 100% efficient. How
effective you expect it to be depends on your conception of
human nature ... But our purpose is not only to see that no
cheating goes on. More than
that, it is to encourage people to
live under an honor system and

to be honorable in their future
life. I'd have absolutely no conception of how really effective
the Honor System at Hopkins is
—of how many violations we've
missed, for instance."
Miller felt that the question of
closed Honor Commission nontrial meetings was not important, since "the things we discuss are usually not that controversial. I have nothing basically against open meetings, but
I don't see any need for students
to attend."
No additional changes are now
planned in the Hopkins Honor
System setup, said Miller, "The
constitution was just revised last
year. We should at least give the
new constitution another year,
maybe two, to see how it's working, before we change anything."

Dr.Glass To Attend Confabs
As Top American Scientist
Dr. H. Bentley Glass, Johns
Hopkins University Professor of
Biology, will leave on Thursday,
December 17, to fly to Europe
where he will attend two international scientific conferences
before' returning to the United
States on Christmas.
In London Dr. Glass will attend a two day meeting of the
Pugwash Continuing Committee
as one of two American scientists
representing the U. S. The group
is an international association of
scientists interested in lessening
the dangers of war, which had
among its founders such men as
Albert Einstein and Bertrand
Russell. The name "Pugwash" is

drawn from the group's original
meeting place at the estate of
Cleveland financier 'Cyrus Eaton
in Pugwash, Nova Scotia.
After the London meeting Dr.
Glass will journey to Monte
Carlo to attend the UNESCOAbstracting
ICSU
sponsored
Board meeting. This conference
is designed to discuss the best
ways and means of abstracting
English language scientific publications for distribution.
Upon his return to the U. S.
Dr. Glass will fly to Chicago to
attend the annual meeting of the
American Association for the Advancement of Science where he
will make two speeches.

Mark Dollard (center) discusses an impending customer service problem with two of his supervisors. •

There's a message for you
in Mark Dollard's progress story
Mark C. Dollard earned his B.A. degree
in English from Yale University in June,
1955. He joined the New York Telephone
Company the following July 18th. Three
and a half years later, he became a District Manager for the company in New
York City—with a staff of 87 people reporting to him and responsibility for
49,000 customer accounts.
Mark's choice of a telephone career came
after numerous job interviews in a variety
of business fields. "What sold me," he
says,"was the telephone company's reputation for solid managerial training, stability and growth. And I was impressed
by the high caliber of people I met during
my visit to the company."
And those are the things to which Mark
credits his rapid advancement. His training during his first two years covered a
wide range of activities...including the
handling of customer contacts in the
business office, selling communications

services to brisinessmen and supervising a
business office.
"It was the company's vigorous growth
that created the opportunity for me to become District Manager in January, 1959,"
Mark points out.
"What I like most about my present position is the variety of managerial responsibilities I have," he says. "It's interesting,
stimulating work. I deal with sales and
marketing programs, handle personnel
problems and make a lot of public relations contacts."
The message for you? Stability, growth,
systematic training and genuine advancement opportunities all add up to rewarding
careers with the Bell Telephone Companies.
Be sure to look into the opportunities for
you. Talk with the Bell interviewer when
he visits your campus — and read the Bell
Telephone booklet on fide in your Placement Office. You'll like what you learn.

Must an organization which purports to represent
the student body find it necessary to hide from them,
when, without having adequately screened the applicants,
it seeks to fill positions which call for representation of
that student body?

Justice

Tomorrow afternoon five students will appear before
the Dormitory Students Representatives Council for a
hearing resulting from last Tuesday's "revival" demonstrations at the dormitories.
As a third party which has no say in the final judgment of the DSRC and Dean Morrill, we offer the following considerations:
The so-called "riot".was not of malicious intent and
was little more than a demonstration; statements about
"disappointment" in the students and "pointlessness" in
the demonstrations cannot be taken into court proceedings
(in other words, personal viewpoints are misguiding
justiciers) ; no one left the campus nor caused any actual
destruction; three of the five accused were only involved
in speech-making; and there was no single or dominating
leader of the demonstrations.
An important precedent may be set tomorrow. The
above considerations could, but must not be overlooked
in the hearings, when students (who are notorious for
their biases) sit to judge other students whose futures
may be at stake.
We only hope that power and justice will not be
confused in the shuffle.

plain-clothes police branch, was named after Wally Scotland and
Fred Yard who invented plain clothes. The American plainclothes force is called the F.B.I. after Frank B. Inchcliff, who
invented fingerprints. Before Mr. Inchcliff's invention, everybody's fingers were absolutely glassy smooth. This, as you may
imagine, played hob with the identification of pewborn babies
in hospitals. From 1791 until 1904 no American parent ever
brought home the right baby from the hospital. This later became known as the Black Tom Explosion.
(But I digress. England, I was saying, wants to trade %les
for a desert. Sweden 'wants to 'trade Lapland for Frank B.

hospitals is so haphazard that Swedes flatly refuse to bring
their babies home. There are, at present, nearly a half-billion
unclaimed babies in Swedish hospitals-sonie of them well over
eighty years ol(1.)

third-floor
further cries of "Give Us a sign"

He pretended to jump out the

Third Leader
Still ,a third potential- leader
appeared in the form of a bespectacled student pushed up on
the wall by members of the
flock. His attempts at a sermon
could not be heard above the
hallelujuah's and other exhortations, both sacred and profane,
.
coming from the mob.
But the bearded-one remained
supreme. "Who's going to win
the world series?" they begged.
"There's not going to be any
world series," he replied, his
voice overflowing with omnicience.
"Save Goucher" someone cried;
but the bearded one quelled the
multitude. With pillow in hand,
he cried: "You shall never see
.this school another year." "Yea,"
yelled the mob. He continued:
"You shall never see Baltimore
another year." Again he was
greeted with an enormous "yea."
"You must renounce violence,"
he demanded. "Boo," they responded.
Gabriel, Too
"We want Gabriel," they
pleaded. And suddenly the sound

of a bugle, playing "Taps" was
heard in the background. The
sound of fire crackers erupted
and the bugle was silenced.
"We denounce you," they
shouted, pulling their leader
from his perch. Fire crackers
sounded; a large number of students had already left to take
English writing absolution examinations, and the rest began
slowly the return to their rooms.
The News-Letter discovered
that word of the dire predictions

mentioned earlier had reached
the Naval Academy, Goucher,
and
Dickinson,
Georgetown
Abbington.
One Goucherite
questioned as to her school's reactions to the forebodings, said:
"The girls are discussing them,
but handling them in an intelligent manner."
Recurrent laughter throughout the proceedings Tuesday
night gave many the impression
that the loud-voiced fervor was
something less than sincere.

Mason-Dixon Conference
Lists Basketball Changes
The Mason-Dixon Conference
has announced a change in its
league set-up and in the tournament arrangement for the basketball season of 1959-60. The
new rules have been instituted
in an attempt to provide an incentive for the conference "alsorans" and also to allow postseason tourney games to be
played in as many gymnasiums
as possible during each year.
Under the new arrangement,
there will be two divisions, a
Northern and Southern, composed of seven and eight teams,
respectively.
The Northern division will
consist of Johns Hopkins, Loyola. Baltimore U., Mt. St. Mary's,
Western Maryland, Towson State
Teachers, and Washington College.
The Southern division will be

At the end of the season, four
teams in each division will go
to the Tournament (which will
probably be held at Catholic U.).
The participating clubs will be
chosen by divisional playoffs,
which will be played at a different school within the division
each year. (The Northern playoff will be held in 1960 at Western Maryland).
Three games are to be held
in the North and four in the
South, with the divisional winners going to the tourney. Since
there are only seven teams in
the North, the divisional winner
draws a bye and thereby receives
a free ride to the tournament.

FLASH: Johns Hopkins dropped a heartbreaker at Delaware,
81-58 this Weds. night. The
lopsided score however gives no
indication of the tremendous
fight put up by the Jays against
a team vastly superior in height.

Hen lead of twelve points to end
the half in a tie. The score kept
fairly even until the final minutes when the Hens jumped ahead
by 20 points.

)ebaters Sponsor Contest

The johns Hopkins University
Debate Council held its first
High School Debate Tournament
this Past week.

stated he felt that "although
it was not as well attended as
had been expected, we were very
happy with the high caliber of
the debating and the assurances
of close co-operation from David
A. Turner, of Washington-Lee
High School of Arlington, Virginia, to aid in rounding up
many schools from the Washington and North Virginia area."

Von the tournament followed
Closely by City College of Baltimore and Parkville High.

sPeaking contest won by Caro137n Craven of Washington-Lee
Which was termed by Hopkins

The Johns Hopkins,University
Jewish Students Association announced its program for the
1959-60 school year. Lectures and
mixers are scheduled on Sunday
nights at 8 p.m. in the Sherwood
Room of Levering Hall.
This week's program will feature a talk by Rabbi Samuel
Rosenblatt entitled "The Bible
Looks at Sex." As with all JSA
affairs, a mixer will follow and is
open to all JSA members free
and for $.50 to all non-members.
Among other things which will
be presented by the group, are
talks on "The Jew in American
Life Today," a Symposium on the
Three Branches of Judaism, the
Annual Passover Sader and a
movie and talk on Israel's role
in Africa and Asia.

arnstormers Present Comedy Tonight National Defense Program

The Johns Hopkins University Barnstormers will continue
their successful all-comedy policy
as they present N. Richard
Nash's "The Rainmaker," a
Poetic" comedy in three acts,
tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 in
Shriver Hall.
The play enjoyed lengthy success on the Broadway stage and
Was later adapted into a movie
starring
Katherine Hepburn,
/31-irt Lancaster and Wendell
Corey. Set on a farm in the
rnicl-west, it concerns the plight
of a "plain" girl unhappily resigned to a fate as an old maid.
The continued efforts of her
father and brother to introduce
her to eligible bachelors meet
With no success, but she is eventually awakened to love by the
Poetic advances of a wandering
cen-man who claims to be able
to cause rainfall at will.
The lively plot thickens when
the girl and the community discover that the "rainmaker" is
a fraud and his escape forces
everyone to make some important decisions.
Lester Wolfe will direct the
Production, which stars Judy
8lank as Lizzie, the heroine:
Pete Berest as Starbuck, the
een-man, and Ralph Bonaker as
41. C. Curry, one of Lizzie's reluctant suitors. Supporting roles
Will be played by Chips Lickson,
Pete Adams and Gordon Bockher. Dick McCarty and Webster
vord are in charge of props, sets
and lighting.

Numerous Freshmen Flunk
Honor Commission Tests
Honor Commission Chairman
Cleveland Miller said this week
that it is "my impression" that
more freshmen this year than in
former years had to be privately
interviewed as a result of the
tests they took on the Honor
System at the end of Orientation
Week.
A regular part of each year's
program,
Orientation
Honor
these tests are used to determine how well incoming freshmen understand the principles
of the Honor System at Johns
Hopkins. Students whose tests
reveal inadequate understanding
receive further instruction by
members of the Commission.
Miller said, however, that this

apparent result of the tests is
not final, since "the results are
not completely in yet, nor can
they really be judged for four
more years." He continued, "I'm
not sure of the cause for this—
whether it's the result of our
tougher marking system this
year or of bad orientation on
our part. I don't think that it's
because of bad orientation, because from talking to Honor
Commission members who spoke
to the different Orientation
groups, I think that this part
of it went off well. So I'm inclined to think this is owing to
another source, and I'm not sure
what this other source is .. . It
might, in fact, be more effective

The National Defense Education Act of 1958 has
generated enough nationwide electricity to cause a growing number of schools to refuse or drop the loan program
it features.
A special News-Letter survey has pinpointed tile
disclaimer affidavit (see insert, below) as the prime cause
for the controversy and disclosed several interesting sidelights among views of college presidents who oppose the
program as it now stands.
The Act itself, of which the loan provision is a part,
provides for nine government dollars to match every
one dollar the institution puts up for scholarships for
students who qualify, particularly those who plan to
teach in the public schools, or those who show superior
capacity in science, engineering, mathematics or modern
foreign language.
Applicants must in discussion show need for scholarship,aid, take an oath of allegiance to the United States,
its Constitution and laws and sign an affidavit of disbelief in organizations teaching

Zealots lot As Earth Nears End
By HARRY LAMBRIGHT
Is the end of the world coming in January? A number of
Hopkins students seem to think
so.
Something between a revival
meeting and a small-scale riot
broke out in front of the old
dorms Tuesday night as approximately 75 students raised cain
for about an hour and a half,
and succeded in attracting the
attention of a Baltimore Sun
reporter.
There had been pinned up on
the dormitory post office bulletin
board notices to the effect that
certain prognostications, made
by men whose predictions had
proven remarkably accurate in
the past, alleged that World War
III would begin in January and
would annihilate most of the
world's inhabitants.
Dire Forebodings
The reports noted that Nostradamus, a medieval monk
famed for his ability to foresee
the future, had .stated that
World War III would start between January 1 - 3, 1960; and
that Padre Pio, a man who had
predicted the dates of World
War I and II and the Korean
War, had warned that on the

coldest day of January, 1960, a
cataclasm would occur which
would result in 80% of the
world's population being slaughtered. He further predicted that
President Dwight Eisenhower
would be assassinated in New
Delhi this week.
In addition, a note was posted
which revealed that there was a
letter from the Fatima apparition, of the first quarter of this
century, which was to be opened
on January 1, 1960, and which
was "very important."
How true any of these allegations were the News-Letter was
unable to determine; what is true
is that they were sufficient excuse for a number of frenzied
zealots to congregate outside the
old dorm to follow the incantations of a bearded self-styled
leader in cheers, shouts, singing
of religious songs, the explosion
of fire crackers, and the election
of a Messiah.
"Repent," Yells Leader
"Repent," yelled the bearded
one, framed in the glow of several flashlights as he stood on
the wall of the dormitory courtyard.
Immediately his "followers"
exploded in unison with "Give

Me That Old Time Religion,"
"Swing Low, Sweet Chariot" and
"The Battle Hymn of the Republic."
"Are there any non-believers
among us?" questioned their
leader, and a mixture of "yeas"

and "nays" answered.
Activity was not limited to the
courtyard, however, for lights in
Vincent and Willard Houses kept
flashing on and off to simulate
lightning. A silhouette in a
(Continued on Page 8)

How effective?
Questioned about the effectiveness of the Honor System at
Hopkins, Miller said, "You have
to realize that an honor system
can never be 100% efficient. How
effective you expect it to be depends on your conception of
human nature ... But our purpose is not only to see that no
cheating goes on. More than
that, it is to encourage people to
live under an honor system and

to be honorable in their future
life. I'd have absolutely no conception of how really effective
the Honor System at Hopkins is
—of how many violations we've
missed, for instance."
Miller felt that the question of
closed Honor Commission nontrial meetings was not important, since "the things we discuss are usually not that controversial. I have nothing basically against open meetings, but
I don't see any need for students
to attend."
No additional changes are now
planned in the Hopkins Honor
System setup, said Miller, "The
constitution was just revised last
year. We should at least give the
new constitution another year,
maybe two, to see how it's working, before we change anything."

Dr. H. Bentley Glass, Johns
Hopkins University Professor of
Biology, will leave on Thursday,
December 17, to fly to Europe
where he will attend two international scientific conferences
before' returning to the United
States on Christmas.
In London Dr. Glass will attend a two day meeting of the
Pugwash Continuing Committee
as one of two American scientists
representing the U. S. The group
is an international association of
scientists interested in lessening
the dangers of war, which had
among its founders such men as
Albert Einstein and Bertrand
Russell. The name "Pugwash" is

drawn from the group's original
meeting place at the estate of
Cleveland financier 'Cyrus Eaton
in Pugwash, Nova Scotia.

Glass will journey to Monte
Carlo to attend the UNESCOAbstracting
ICSU
sponsored
Board meeting. This conference
is designed to discuss the best
ways and means of abstracting
English language scientific publications for distribution.
Upon his return to the U. S.
Dr. Glass will fly to Chicago to
attend the annual meeting of the
American Association for the Advancement of Science where he
will make two speeches.

Mark Dollard (center) discusses an impending customer service problem with two of his supervisors. •

There's a message for you
in Mark Dollard's progress story
Mark C. Dollard earned his B.A. degree
in English from Yale University in June,
1955. He joined the New York Telephone
Company the following July 18th. Three
and a half years later, he became a District Manager for the company in New
York City—with a staff of 87 people reporting to him and responsibility for
49,000 customer accounts.
Mark's choice of a telephone career came
after numerous job interviews in a variety
of business fields. "What sold me," he
says,"was the telephone company's reputation for solid managerial training, stability and growth. And I was impressed
by the high caliber of people I met during
my visit to the company."
And those are the things to which Mark
credits his rapid advancement. His training during his first two years covered a
wide range of activities...including the
handling of customer contacts in the
business office, selling communications

services to brisinessmen and supervising a
business office.
"It was the company's vigorous growth
that created the opportunity for me to become District Manager in January, 1959,"
Mark points out.
"What I like most about my present position is the variety of managerial responsibilities I have," he says. "It's interesting,
stimulating work. I deal with sales and
marketing programs, handle personnel
problems and make a lot of public relations contacts."
The message for you? Stability, growth,
systematic training and genuine advancement opportunities all add up to rewarding
careers with the Bell Telephone Companies.
Be sure to look into the opportunities for
you. Talk with the Bell interviewer when
he visits your campus — and read the Bell
Telephone booklet on fide in your Placement Office. You'll like what you learn.

Justice

Tomorrow afternoon five students will appear before
the Dormitory Students Representatives Council for a
hearing resulting from last Tuesday's "revival" demonstrations at the dormitories.
As a third party which has no say in the final judgment of the DSRC and Dean Morrill, we offer the following considerations:
The so-called "riot".was not of malicious intent and
was little more than a demonstration; statements about
"disappointment" in the students and "pointlessness" in
the demonstrations cannot be taken into court proceedings
(in other words, personal viewpoints are misguiding
justiciers) ; no one left the campus nor caused any actual
destruction; three of the five accused were only involved
in speech-making; and there was no single or dominating
leader of the demonstrations.
An important precedent may be set tomorrow. The
above considerations could, but must not be overlooked
in the hearings, when students (who are notorious for
their biases) sit to judge other students whose futures
may be at stake.

Fred Yard who invented plain clothes. The American plainclothes force is called the F.B.I. after Frank B. Inchcliff, who
invented fingerprints. Before Mr. Inchcliff's invention, everybody's fingers were absolutely glassy smooth. This, as you may
imagine, played hob with the identification of pewborn babies
in hospitals. From 1791 until 1904 no American parent ever
brought home the right baby from the hospital. This later became known as the Black Tom Explosion.

hospitals is so haphazard that Swedes flatly refuse to bring
their babies home. There are, at present, nearly a half-billion
unclaimed babies in Swedish hospitals-sonie of them well over
eighty years ol(1.)

third-floor
further cries of "Give Us a sign"
and "Speak" as well as an occasional "Crucify him!"
He pretended to jump out the
window by throwing a pillow to

Third Leader
Still ,a third potential- leader
appeared in the form of a bespectacled student pushed up on
the wall by members of the
flock. His attempts at a sermon
could not be heard above the
hallelujuah's and other exhortations, both sacred and profane,
.
coming from the mob.
But the bearded-one remained
supreme. "Who's going to win
the world series?" they begged.
"There's not going to be any
world series," he replied, his
voice overflowing with omnicience.
"Save Goucher" someone cried;
but the bearded one quelled the
multitude. With pillow in hand,
he cried: "You shall never see
.this school another year." "Yea,"
yelled the mob. He continued:
"You shall never see Baltimore
another year." Again he was
greeted with an enormous "yea."
"You must renounce violence,"
he demanded. "Boo," they responded.
Gabriel, Too
"We want Gabriel," they
pleaded. And suddenly the sound

of a bugle, playing "Taps" was
heard in the background. The
sound of fire crackers erupted
and the bugle was silenced.
"We denounce you," they
shouted, pulling their leader
from his perch. Fire crackers
sounded; a large number of students had already left to take
English writing absolution examinations, and the rest began
slowly the return to their rooms.
The News-Letter discovered
that word of the dire predictions

mentioned earlier had reached
the Naval Academy, Goucher,
and
Dickinson,
Georgetown
Abbington.
One Goucherite
questioned as to her school's reactions to the forebodings, said:
"The girls are discussing them,
but handling them in an intelligent manner."
Recurrent laughter throughout the proceedings Tuesday
night gave many the impression
that the loud-voiced fervor was
something less than sincere.

Dr. Fritz Machlup, professor
of political economy at The
Johns Hopkins University, was
installed as President of the
Southern Economic Association
last month in Jacksonville,

Florida.
The installation took place at
the Association's annual meeting.
Dr. Machlup will serve a oneyear term in office. A native of
Austria, Dr. Machlup has been at
Johns Hopkins University since
1947.
He holds the Abram G. Hutzler
Professorship in Political Economy. .

Mason-Dixon Conference
Lists Basketball Changes
The Mason-Dixon Conference
has announced a change in its
league set-up and in the tournament arrangement for the basketball season of 1959-60. The
new rules have been instituted
in an attempt to provide an incentive for the conference "alsorans" and also to allow postseason tourney games to be
played in as many gymnasiums
as possible during each year.
Under the new arrangement,
there will be two divisions, a
Northern and Southern, composed of seven and eight teams,
respectively.
The Northern division will
consist of Johns Hopkins, Loyola. Baltimore U., Mt. St. Mary's,
Western Maryland, Towson State
Teachers, and Washington College.
The Southern division will be

At the end of the season, four
teams in each division will go
to the Tournament (which will
probably be held at Catholic U.).
The participating clubs will be
chosen by divisional playoffs,
which will be played at a different school within the division
each year. (The Northern playoff will be held in 1960 at Western Maryland).
Three games are to be held
in the North and four in the
South, with the divisional winners going to the tourney. Since
there are only seven teams in
the North, the divisional winner
draws a bye and thereby receives
a free ride to the tournament.

FLASH: Johns Hopkins dropped a heartbreaker at Delaware,
81-58 this Weds. night. The
lopsided score however gives no
indication of the tremendous
fight put up by the Jays against
a team vastly superior in height.
They displayed lots of heart and
hustle by cutting an early Blue
Hen lead of twelve points to end
the half in a tie. The score kept
fairly even until the final minutes when the Hens jumped ahead
by 20 points.

OMEWOOD., BALTIMORE, DEC. II, 1959

)ebaters Sponsor Contest
For Nearby High Schools
The johns Hopkins University
Debate Council held its first
High School Debate Tournament
this Past week.
Chairman W a 11 y Orlinsky
stated he felt that "although
it was not as well attended as
had been expected, we were very
happy with the high caliber of
the debating and the assurances
of close co-operation from David
A. Turner, of Washington-Lee
High School of Arlington, Virginia, to aid in rounding up
many schools from the Washington and North Virginia area."
Washington-Lee High School
Von the tournament followed
Closely by City College of Baltimore and Parkville High.
The highlight of the day, however, was the extemporaneous
sPeaking contest won by Caro137n Craven of Washington-Lee
Which was termed by Hopkins
bebate Council President Stuart
Handwerger The most masterful Piece of speaking I have ever
heard in four years of debating
at any level." Miss Craven spoke
for three minutes on a picture
called "Jewelled Stones."
The leading debaters were Jon
Sc'hen, Washington-Lee; Eddie
Block, City College; Stephen
Baer, City College, and Carolyn
Craven, Washington-Lee.
Mat Watson was named chairMan of next year's High School
bebate Tournament and has antounced plans to hold a two-day
lirogr
complete with panel
discussions and an address by
leading men in the field on the
topic to be debated. The pro-

gram will be co-sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins University Admissions Office.

Mixers, Speakers
On JSA Program
For Coming Year

YOU LOOK

The Johns Hopkins,University
Jewish Students Association announced its program for the
1959-60 school year. Lectures and
mixers are scheduled on Sunday
nights at 8 p.m. in the Sherwood
Room of Levering Hall.
This week's program will feature a talk by Rabbi Samuel
Rosenblatt entitled "The Bible
Looks at Sex." As with all JSA
affairs, a mixer will follow and is
open to all JSA members free
and for $.50 to all non-members.
Among other things which will
be presented by the group, are
talks on "The Jew in American
Life Today," a Symposium on the
Three Branches of Judaism, the
Annual Passover Sader and a
movie and talk on Israel's role
in Africa and Asia.
